snippet: Seventy-three percent of New Yorkers said they were optimistic about the next four years, but skeptical that Bill de Blasio could achieve changes on issues that defined his candidacy.
abstract: New York Times/Siena College poll shows that 73 percent of New Yorkers say they are optimistic about Bill de Blasio's mayoralty; many are skeptical, however,l that he can achieve changes on issues that defined his candidacy, like widening gap between the rich and poor and the scarcity of affordable housing in New York City.

byline.original: By KATE TAYLOR and DALIA SUSSMAN
byline.contributor: Allison Kopicki, Marina Stefan and Megan Thee-Brenan contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Seventy-three percent of New Yorkers said they were optimistic about the next four years, but skeptical that Bill de Blasio could achieve changes on issues that defined his candidacy.

headline.main: Poll Finds Hope Is Running High for Next Mayor of New York City
headline.print_headline: Poll Finds Hope Is Running High For Next Mayor
